skill: Student can partition a 0-1 number line into equal intervals using the halving strategy (denominators 2, 4, 8)
problem_type: Student places tick marks to divide a blank number line into halves, fourths, or eighths
workspace_description: Blank horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with only endpoint labels.
prompt_examples: Divide this line into fourths.
Place tick marks between 0 and 1 to make 4 equal spaces.
Partition this number line into halves.
Create 8 equal intervals on this line.
Use the halving method to mark fourths.
action_description: Student clicks on the number line to place tick marks.
correct_end_state: All tick marks placed at correct positions creating equal intervals.
success_dialogue: Right. Four equal spaces.
Yes. You divided it into halves.
Good, eight equal intervals.

skill: Student can partition a 0-1 number line into equal intervals using equal-jump (3) or combination (6) strategies
problem_type: Student places tick marks to divide a blank number line into thirds, or sixths
workspace_description: Blank horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with only endpoint labels.
prompt_examples: Divide this line into thirds.
Place tick marks to make 3 equal spaces.
Partition this number line into sixths.
action_description: Student clicks on the number line to place tick marks.
correct_end_state: All tick marks placed at correct positions. For thirds: ticks at 1/3, 2/3. For sixths: ticks at 1/6, 2/6, 3/6, 4/6, 5/6.
success_dialogue: Good. Three equal spaces.
Yes. You made sixths.
Right, you made six equal intervals.

skill: Student can label tick mark positions by counting intervals from zero
problem_type: Student drags fraction labels to correct tick mark positions on a pre-partitioned number line
workspace_description: Pre-partitioned horizontal number line with tick marks already placed. Label palette with draggable fraction labels. Endpoints (0 and 1) labeled; other positions unlabeled or partially labeled.
prompt_examples: Label each tick mark with the correct fraction.
Drag the labels to show the fractions.
Place the fraction labels on the number line.
Label the first tick mark.
Complete the labels for this number line.
action_description: Student drags fraction labels from the palette to the corresponding tick mark positions, counting spaces from zero to determine correct placement.
correct_end_state: All tick marks correctly labeled. Labels show correct fractions at each position (e.g., 1/4, 2/4, 3/4 for fourths).
success_dialogue: Right. The numerator of each label shows how many spaces from zero.
Yes, 1/4 at the first tick, 2/4 at the second.
Correct, 2/4 is two intervals from 0.

skill: Student can identify what fraction is represented by a point on a partitioned 0-1 number line
problem_type: Student identifies the fraction shown by a point already placed on a pre-partitioned number line
workspace_description: Pre-partitioned horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with a point placed at one tick position. Multiple choice options show possible fraction answers.
prompt_examples: What fraction does this point show?
Name the fraction at this location.
What fraction is marked on the line?
Identify this fraction.
action_description: Student examines the point on the number line, counts intervals from zero, and selects the correct fraction from multiple choice options.
correct_end_state: Correct fraction selected from multiple choice options.
success_dialogue: Right. Three intervals from zero is 3/4.
Yes,that's 2/3.
Good. You counted two intervals from zero.

skill: Student understands that the denominator stays constant across a partitioned line
problem_type: Student identifies that the bottom number stays the same across fractions on a line
workspace_description: Pre-partitioned number line with fraction labels shown (e.g., 1/4, 2/4, 3/4). Multiple choice asking what stays the same (options: the bottom number, the top number, the position).
prompt_examples: What stays the same for all the fractions on this line?
Look at 1/4, 2/4, 3/4. What number doesn't change?
What do all these fractions have in common?
Which part of the fraction stays the same?
action_description: Student examines the labeled fractions and selects 'the bottom number' to identify denominator constancy.
correct_end_state: 'The bottom number' selected from multiple choice options.
success_dialogue: Yes, the bottom number - denominator - stays the same.
Right. The denominator tells us our interval  size.
Good. We're always counting the same-sized intervals.
Correct. The 4 stays because we're counting fourths.

skill: Student understands that n/n equals 1 whole
problem_type: Student places n/n at position 1 or identifies that n/n = 1
workspace_description: Pre-partitioned number line with some fraction labels shown. Drag palette with n/n label (e.g., 4/4, 3/3), or MCQ asking what n/n equals.
prompt_examples: Where does 4/4 go on this line?
Place 3/3 on the number line.
What does 6/6 equal?
3/3 equals how much?
action_description: Student drags n/n label to position 1, or selects '1 whole' from multiple choice.
correct_end_state: n/n label placed at position 1, or '1 whole' selected.
success_dialogue: Right! 4/4 equals 1 whole.
Yes. Three thirds is one whole.
Correct. All the intervals make the whole.
Good, 6/6 lands right at 1.

skill: Student can partition a 0-2 number line into equal intervals for fractions beyond 1
problem_type: Student places tick marks to partition an extended number line from 0 to 2
workspace_description: Extended horizontal number line from 0 to 2 with endpoint labels (0, 1, 2). May have 0-1 section pre-partitioned for scaffolding. Student clicks to place tick marks.
prompt_examples: Divide the line from 0 to 1 and from 1 to 2 into thirds.
Partition each whole into fourthsâ€”from 0 to 1, then 1 to 2.
Make sixths in each section: 0 to 1 and 1 to 2.
Show fifths from 0 to 1, then continue the same spacing to 2.
action_description: Student clicks on the extended number line to place tick marks creating equal intervals that continue past 1, maintaining the same spacing before and after 1.
correct_end_state: All tick marks placed at correct positions. Intervals visually equal from 0 through 2. Same spacing before and after 1.
success_dialogue: Right. The same spacing of fourths continues past 1.
Good, fourths all the way to 2.
Yes. The intervals of fourths stay equal beyond 1.
Nice work extending the pattern of fourths beyond 1.

skill: Student can label fractions beyond 1 on extended number lines
problem_type: Student drags fraction labels to tick positions beyond 1 on a 0-2 number line
workspace_description: Extended 0-2 number line, pre-partitioned. Labels for 0-1 section may be pre-placed. Drag palette with beyond-1 fractions (e.g., 4/3, 5/4, 7/6).
prompt_examples: Label the tick mark that shows 4/3.
Place the label for 5/4.
What comes after 3/3? Label it.
Drag 7/6 to its position.
Label the fractions past 1.
action_description: Student drags fraction labels from the palette to the correct tick mark positions beyond 1, counting intervals from zero.
correct_end_state: Correct labels placed at positions beyond 1.
success_dialogue: Yes! Four thirds means four intervals from 0.
Right. We keep counting: 4/3, 5/3...
Good. 5/4 is five spaces from zero.
Correct, the pattern of thirds continues beyond 1.

skill: Student can identify fractions beyond 1 from a placed point
problem_type: Student identifies what fraction is represented by a point placed beyond 1 on a 0-2 number line
workspace_description: Extended 0-2 number line, pre-partitioned, with a point placed at a tick position beyond 1. Multiple choice options show possible fraction answers.
prompt_examples: What fraction is at this point?
Identify the fraction shown.
The point is at what position?
Name this fraction.
What fraction does this point show?
action_description: Student examines the point beyond 1, counts intervals from zero, and selects the correct fraction from multiple choice options.
correct_end_state: Correct fraction selected from multiple choice options.
success_dialogue: Right. Five spaces from zero is 5/4.
Yes, that's 4/3, four intervals from 0.
Correct. You counted all the intervals from zero.
Good, 7/6 is seven sixths intervals from 0.

skill: Student can count intervals (not tick marks) to determine fraction positions
problem_type: Student answers diagnostic questions about counting intervals versus tick marks
workspace_description: Pre-partitioned number line from 0 to 1. Multiple choice options for interval counting questions. For error detection: scenario describes someone counting ticks incorrectly.
prompt_examples: How many equal intervals are between 0 and 1?
This point is 3 spaces from zero. What fraction is it?
Sam counted 5 tick marks and said the line shows fifths. Is Sam correct?
Count the intervals. How many equal parts?
The point is how many intervals from zero?
action_description: Student reads the question, examines the number line, and selects the correct answer demonstrating understanding that we count spaces/intervals, not tick marks.
correct_end_state: Correct answer selected demonstrating understanding of intervals vs. ticks.
success_dialogue: Right. We count spaces, not tick marks.
Yes, 4 equal spaces means fourths.
Correct. Sam counted marks, but we count intervals.
Good. Three spaces from zero is 3/4.

skill: Student can partition a line using halving strategy, then label all tick marks
problem_type: Two-step: Student partitions into halves/fourths/eighths, then labels positions
workspace_description: Step 1: Blank 0-1 number line for partitioning. Step 2: After partition validated, label palette appears for labeling all positions.
prompt_examples: Divide this line into fourths, then label each position.
Make halves, then add the labels.
Partition into eighths and label them.
First create equal spaces, then show the fractions.
action_description: Student first places tick marks to partition the line (step 1), then drags fraction labels to all tick positions (step 2).
correct_end_state: Line partitioned with equal intervals AND all tick marks correctly labeled.
success_dialogue: Good, equal spacing of fourths and correct labels.
Right. You partitioned and labeled fourths.
That's the two-step method.

skill: Student can partition a line using equal-jump/combination strategy, then label all tick marks
problem_type: Two-step: Student partitions into thirds/sixths, then labels positions
workspace_description: Step 1: Blank 0-1 number line for partitioning. Step 2: After partition validated, label palette appears for labeling all positions.
prompt_examples: Divide this line into thirds, then label each position.
Make sixths, then add the labels.
First create equal spaces, then show the fractions.
action_description: Student first places tick marks to partition the line (step 1), then drags fraction labels to all tick positions (step 2).
correct_end_state: Line partitioned with equal intervals AND all tick marks correctly labeled.
success_dialogue: Good, equal spacing for thirds and correct labels.
Right. You partitioned and labeled thirds.
That's the two-step method.

skill: Student can partition a 0-2 line, then label fractions beyond 1
problem_type: Two-step: Student partitions extended line, then labels positions including beyond 1
workspace_description: Step 1: Blank or partially-partitioned 0-2 number line. Step 2: After partition validated, label palette appears for labeling positions beyond 1.
prompt_examples: Divide the line from 0 to 1 and from 1 to 2 into fourths, then label the fractions past 1.
Partition each whole into thirds, then label 4/3 and 5/3.
Make sixths in both sections, then label the positions beyond 1.
Show fifths from 0 to 1 and from 1 to 2, then add the labels past 1.
action_description: Student first places tick marks to partition the 0-2 line (step 1), then drags fraction labels to positions beyond 1 (step 2).
correct_end_state: Extended line partitioned with equal intervals AND beyond-1 positions correctly labeled.
success_dialogue: Good, the pattern of fourths continues past 1.
Right. Equal spacing for fourths and correct labels all the way.
Nice work extending equal intervals and labeling fourths.
You've got the full method. Partition first, then label.
